title: Rapman 3.1 Bearing Blocks, X and Y, for dual and single head machines
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These bearing blocks will encase your linear bearings snugly and securely. Never again will you have to choose between damaging your rods, bearings, and plates by overtightening the bolts or leaving them too loose and having half the nuts spin off during superfast prints. >.<
Updates from jcoffland's original:
The orientation has changed; they are now set up to print flat. This means the weakest direction is no longer along the axis of the bolts, which in previous versions could cause them to delaminate and split.
Because of the orientation change, the nut rebates now have lofted cuts so they can still be printed without support.
The interfaces for the bearing holes and bolt holes have been modified so that the inside should not need filing. My bearings slid in perfectly straight off the printer -- snug but smooth.
There is now a version for the dual head carriage as well as the single head.

UPDATE: I've uploaded the IGES files. Let me know if anything's missing and you need it, it's been a while since I looked at these. I considered shaving off a couple mm per Fred_T below, but my blocks snapped over my rails with no problem. Print one and if yours don't you might think about modifying the print. They do take some force but not undue amounts. I also didn't run into warping or shrinkage with my ABS but that's probably machine-dependent and might also be due to my running at 2 or 3x speeds :). If you see warping his suggestion of decreased infill is a good one. Print with your favorite settings. No need to go overboard since there aren't really any bending loads and the bolt loads are in the strong direction. I recommend somewhere around 25% infill (or even less if you have shrinkage problems) and 2 extra skins to help with the nut recess overhang. You will need one of each file except that there are two versions of one of the X axis blocks; you will need the one that corresponds to your carriage setup. Both carriages need three blocks and two are identical, but the back block on the single head carriage and the front left block on the double head need a cutout for the extruder bolt heads. The two identical X axis blocks are actually together in one STL file, but if you need individual ones let me know. Install as per jcoffland's original blocks. The big top acrylic plates stay; these just replace the bottom plates. One important note: I don't like jcoffland's method of keeping the X belt holders rigid; it puts too much strain on the carriage plate for my liking. Then again, I print kinda fast, and also I am a wuss and have seen too many acrylic parts snap under fatigue. If you're comfortable with it that's cool. Otherwise, here's what I did (unfortunately it takes extra hardware, which makes it a rather inelegant solution): Get six M5 x 40mm bolts, and fasten in the X blocks as usual but use 4 of the slightly longer bolts, two in the front and two in the back. Use the other two 40mm bolts as the belt holders instead of the original 35mm. Take the original bottom carriage plate and place it underneath the bearing blocks, around the ends of the 40mm bolts. Secure the plate with a washer and second nut on the ends of the 4 long bolts that go through the bearing blocks (see picture). This avoids any cantilever on the belt holders. NOTE: Using these bearing blocks will make your axes 0.5 mm taller. Installing them on both X and Y axes will raise your extruder 1 mm (ish). You'll need to re-set your Z height or adjust the Z limit switch trigger bolt. Or both.

comments.text:
Nice work :)
You have licensed these as CC BY SA NC, but the original was CC BY SA. Under those conditions, you should also use CC BY SA.
comments.author: bobc

comments.text: I made a set and here's some feedback. At first I had some warping problem using ABS. I resolved it by adjusting bed height and lowering the fill to 15% instead of 25% as proposed. I thing 25% is a bit too much and creates shrinkage. I used 1.5X speed multiplier and it ran fast and smooth. The distance allowing the blocks to fit on the bars was just a bit too narrow, an extra 1 mm or 2 would eliminate the need to file. Anyway I'm happy with it, thank you. I might try to create a part that would attach the X belt safely.
comments.author: Fred_T

comments.text: I like these; working on doing these, your X and Y rod clamps, and chylld's full complement of corners.  Only difference is, I'm trying the - perhaps overkill - step of investment casting them, on the notion of trusting metal more than plastic.  ;)
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: I myself am a fan of overkill (working on retrofitting the entire RapMan with trapezoidal threaded Z rods...). :-D
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: My intent is to shift the holes a little bit and drill them out to use larger fasteners for a first try.  If that doesn't work adequately, thin out the arms a little bit on the mill, and possibly use some loctite to help convince things to stay.  I figure if after casting I ream the things to as close to precisely the same diameter as the rods, maybe they won't have to flex as far for clamping.  Or, I suppose, worst comes to worst, do those out of ABS... ;)
comments.author: caesia

comments.text: It probably would have been fine, since I found out when I went to recheck the part against the original that most of the problem was my Y motor pulley being shoved too far towards the motor. ;) The holes are moved about a millimeter in the new version, which probably makes them off a half millimeter in the other direction now, but nothing that's going to really affect the machine.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Well, I got my test piece to come out (dremel turbine scaled up from this site) so that's promising.  Working on trying to get a big batch of rapman parts ready to cast all at once, as a lot of the wait is burning out the plastic.  And hm, now that I look at it, wondering if I wouldn't be better off just milling these from your design instead of casting them... thoughts.
comments.author: caesia

comments.text: I like my design because I hate using wrenches to hold nuts... so you'd definitely lose that if you were milling them unless you did something really fancy with the corners. I'm not sure I see that much of a benefit to making the pillow blocks metal, to be honest - if you're not doing it for the sake of having something to cast, there's no reason these need to be metal since all the stress on the carriage is really taken up by the carriage plates. Plastic would probably hold the bearings a bit better, too. If you're just looking for something to mill, I guess you could make them out of delrin, though. Recommend cutting them slightly shorter since a lot of the height in these is for the nut recesses and if you can't make those you might as well raise up the bottom carriage plate.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Got any videos demonstrating your print speed?  I'd love to seem them.
comments.author: jcoffland

comments.text: I've actually started printing a bit slower, since my objects were getting a distinctly melted look. On big plates I push it up to 48 mm/s, but most of what I'm doing now is little stuff that needs time to cool down. Still jerks the belt around pretty good, but not much to see.
comments.author: jcoffland

title: comboy's puzzle #2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
• Interlocking - it doesn't fall apart when you move it around
  • Printable - no supports necessary
  • 4th level - 4 moves are needed to remove the first piece
  • Puzzle - 5 pieces
    • This is my second puzzle design. Not gonna lie, I'm pretty proud of it :) It took a few iterations though.. Any kind of feedback is extremely valuable to me - how long did it take you to solve it, is offset OK, why it sucks, or whatever else comes to your mind. In thing files you will find two versions: tight and loose. Tight has 0.9mm offset, loose has 0.12mm. When printing it with 0.4mm nozzle and 0.09mm layer width, tight version is perfect to my taste, but if you are printing with lower resolution then probably it's safer to use the loose one (tested it with 0.2mm layer and it's still loose then).

title: Dual Melzi Box for RepRapPro Tricolor Mendel

description.text:
The RepRapPro Tricolor Mendel uses two Melzi controller boards, mounted by default on each side of the frame.  
Rather than go with this arrangement, I decided to modify the existing Melzi Box design to allow you to fit two Melzi boards in the same box.  
The bottom is made tall enough to fit two boards stacked on top of each other, and the top part has the key removed so you can access the MicroSD slots and USB ports without removing the cover.

Top was upside down. Flipped it around and re-uploaded the Top.  
Changed the Standoffs to add a recess for an M3 nut.   
One of the clips on the Top piece snapped off really easily, so I modified the Top to make the clip walls a little thicker (2.0mm vs 1.5mm).

The original parts were imported into Sketchup, and then the surfaces on the Bottom box were raised by 25mm to accommodate the 2nd board.  
The tongue blocking the MicroSD card slots was removed.  
Exported back to STL, repaired via NetFabb, and printed perfectly!  
There are 4 standoffs you will have to print to mount the Slave board on top of the Master, and you will have to find some longer M3 screws to mount them.

1x Bottom
1x Top
4x Standoffs You will have to rotate the Bottom and Top parts by 45 degrees so that they will fit diagonally across your print bed. If you have already wired up your Tricolor Mendel with the Slave board, you may have to re-do the Slave power cable and motor wires to be long enough to reach the left side of the chassis.

Assemble the box by putting long M3 bolts up through the U-clips, through the holes in the Bottom box and through the 1st Melzi board. The screw heads should be on the other side of the U-clips, not inside the box.  
Secure the 1st Melzi board to the box with a washers and M3 nuts.  
At this point, wire up the 1st Melzi board - presumably this will be your Master board.

For the Master-Slave interconnect cable, I would recommend getting a short 3-wire female jumper cable like this:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10363 You'll need to pull a few wires out of the connector to do the TX/RX crossover.

With the boards inside the case, you won't be able to easily access the Reset button. Instead, wire up a cable with a pushbutton switch to act as an external reset button. Get one of these 6" 2-pin jumpers, and cut it in half:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10367 Get a mini momentary pushbutton switch that's a Single-Pole Single-Throw switch. (Search eBay for "mini momentary push button SPST NO"). You'll want one that is a panel-mount kind, with two terminals, and it must be Normally Open (NO). Take the red wires from the jumper wire that you cut in half, twist them together, and solder them to one leg of the switch. Take the yellow wires from the jumper wire, twist them together, and solder them to the other leg of the switch. Attach the Red wires to the Reset pins on both the Master and Slave Melzi boards, on the 6-pin connector on the board. Attach the Yellow wires to the Ground (GND) wires on the boards. The GND pin is right below the Reset pin. When you press the button, both boards will Reset. Drill a hole in the side or top of the box, and mount the pushbutton switch so you can press it without opening the box.

Slide the standoffs on top of the bolts and M3 nuts, and tighten the nuts down - this is what will hold the case and the Master board to the frame.  
Add the 2nd Melzi board (Slave) on top of the standoffs.  
Secure them with washers and M3 nuts.  
Wire up the Slave board, and connect the other end of the jumper cables.  
Snap the top on to the box, and you should be good to go!

author: GiulianoM

description.text:
This is one of several props I put together for a Firefly/Han Solo/Hellboy inspired Steampunk Space Pirate costume for a costume party.
The original gun model by dan0nator is fantastic, but I wanted something that could be snapped together quickly, rather than printed in halves and glued.  Since I was at it, I split the handle from the rest of the gun so that it could be printed in a different color.  Props to Tony Buser for his perennially useful pin connector library.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

15%

Print Order and Assembly Note: If you've got your printer tolerances dialed in, it will take a little bit of force to insert the pins, but it is well worth it. The prop I printed holds together as if it was printed as a solid piece. Every part snapped together tightly with zero post-processing.
  • Print at least 14 pins. I would recommend 16, just in case you lose or break one (~20 minutes)
  • Print the two parts for the handle (~90 hours)
  • Start printing the two parts for the "trigger" area (~2 hours 30 minutes)
  • While the "trigger" parts are printing, use two pins to snap the two handle halves together. Add four more pins to the edge of the handle that connects to the rest of the gun.
  • Start printing the single part for the gun barrel. (~75 minutes)
  • While the barrel part is being printed, use four pins to snap the two "trigger" halves together. Add four more pins to the edge of the "trigger" area that will connect to the barrel.
  • Once the barrel part is done, just snap it into the rest of the gun

I added almost nothing to dan0nator's creation.  I used OpenSCAD to orient and split the model into 5 large pieces for easy printing and aesthetic purposes.  
The handle was split off from the rest of the gun so that I could print it in brown/copper while the rest could be printed in grey/silver.  I split the handle down the middle so that when it was done the handle would appear to have a wood-like grain.  The "trigger" area was also split down the middle so that it could be printed without supports.  The barrel was printed as a single piece, oriented upright, so that it wouldn't have any seams and would help hold the model tightly together.
I did make one minor change to the model.  Rather than splitting the left from right sides, I focused on getting just the left side done as perfectly as I could - then mirroring the file.  This way I didn't have to worry about whether I was cutting the model exactly in half.

comments.text: A quick FYI :  Mal's gun is approx 15" total length,  I guesstimated and printed this at 150% and ended up with a gun with a total length of 16.5".  I would say up scaling the original to 140% would probably be about right (another guesstimate soooo...yeah :) ). Or, you know, actually measure all the pieces in the slicer and do the math before printing :)

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Y extension mod

description.text: UPDATE: Thanks to Sheriandjohn Tompkins for pointing this out, you can use the Y extension mod with the Z brace now!!! ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948 ) I have made them 8 mm shorter to compensate for the Z brace mod so that when both installed, the extension length stays 120mm.

This is a mod to extend the Y axis of the Wanhao Duplicator i3 120mm. You will need: -A longer GT2 Belt (24cm longer)
-2 8mm x 500mm steel rods
-6 M3 size screws (any length will do)
-Change the Max Y in EEPROM to 320
-Cut the two tiewraps that hold the plate cables so that the plate can move further down. A bigger build plate or just longer Glass. And DONT INSTALL IT LIKE I DID! Do it the right way! :) Instructions:
  • Unscrew the fron plate that holds the rods (after loosening the setcrews)
  • Remove belt
  • Place the extensions and screw them in. You dont need long screws...I used M3x5mm ones, the larger the better.
  • Insert the rods
  • The use the same screws as before and screw the plate on the extensions
  • Insert the Belt (1m is enough, the old belt is 76cm long)
    • Done!

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes: Infill percentage can be changed according to preference. I had 25 and it works OK.

title: Guksi (Finnish: kuksa; Swedish: kasa) traditional drinking cup, modern version

description.text:
A Kuksa is a drinking cup traditionally crafted in northern Scandinavia from carved birch burl.  
They come in different sizes, bigger ones for soup and tea, smaller ones for 'high spirits'. I used mine for about 20 years, and it's still usable.  
It has a lanyard hole and can be used for a lot of different things in camp kitchen.  
This is a modern approach to this old craft, size is about 15x10x7 cm (6x4x3 inches).  
Needs some support during printing.

description.text: This is a tool you can use to check if your Y axis is perpendicular to the X axis. Some people, myself included, have printed out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978 and noticed that the cable chain arcs to one side. Investigating the problem I have discovered that my Thing-O-Matic's Y stage is not perpendicular to the X axis. This may be the cause of the arcing problem.

Print. Let cool. Measure the diagonals. Share your results! If your Y axis is perpendicular to the X axis, both measurements will be identical. Please leave a comment with your results. If the error is consistent among many machines we can create a new part to fix it. On my machine the measurement from lower left to upper right (/) is about .65mm longer than lower right to upper left ("backslash")* / = 79.85mm
"backslash"* = 79.21mm *The backslash will not display here but it will in the comments. ** Thanks to those who share their results.

comments.text: For most things, being slightly out of square is not going to make any noticeable difference. If you print something like a cable chain with dozens of links you will find it curving one direction or the other.

description.text: Print in different colors for some simple pawns to use in roleplaying and wargaming figurine battles (I use red for enemies and blue for friendly NPCs).  The numbers are good to use for mooks that don't have individual figurines, like a group of gnolls, so you can keep separate which one is Gnoll #2 and which is Gnoll #5.

These should print without supports or brims.  I find they print much better done one at a time, as annoying as that is.  
The versions that have "supports" in the filename have manually inserted supports to help them print well, but which you can easily cut away with an XActo knife.  You may find you don't need them; if the regular versions print okay for you, so much the better -- many also have better-looking letters and numbers, with more natural curves.  But you'll probably have better luck with the supports versions.

I have a Psion (basically just a psychic monk) character in D&D, but there are no suitable minifigures. I ended up buying a regular monk, clipping off his sword, and modelling a psi-crystal staff for him to use. 
The crystal is intended to be printed from a different color plastic, hence why it is a separate STL.
Note: These are really small! They are hard to print, and depending on your printer, may not come out well. 
Post pictures if you print it please! I would love to see how you use it!
Message me or comment if you have any ideas for things to model that are D&D or RPG related!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Notes: I would recommend printing two of the staffs vertically at the same time and separating them on the build plate so that the print head has to move from one to the other, giving them time to cool. Z-Hop is very helpful here (1mm).

comments.text: You could dremel some rough details into a length of filament and just print the crystal. Alternatively you can just use hot glue, let it cool, and shape it with a craft knife dipped it really hot water.

This is a GoPro Gimbal I've designed around the GBM2804 Hollow Shaft Motors for the White Sheep.
It allows for nice cable management with cable guides and by routing them through the axis they can move freely without tension from the angle of the gimbal. Some parts were salvaged from a cheap Ebay Gimbal like the Vibration dampeners and the Alexmos Board. (I have some arms for these kind of motors aswell ... these files are marked as MADPOWER) The GoPro ist mounted in a Housing and secured by a velcro strap.
Here comes the tricky part ... You have to sew :) (It's really not that difficult with a sewing machine ... Or just ask your mom)
(If you like to live dangerously you could also just trust the friction of the housing to hold it)
The housing allows for a slim FPV cable to the GoPro which you can get here :
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__57996__Super_Slim_GoPro_3_A_V_Cable_And_Power_Lead_For_FPV_UK_Warehouse_.html?strSearch=slim%20fp What to Print?
One of everything - except:
2x TopCap.STL (if you use no FPV Camera)
1x TopCap.STL 1x FPVMount.STL (for FPV Board Cam) ARMGBM2804Fix has no adjustment to balance the Gimbal, but is pretty much the balance point for it. Aswell you can mount the Zip Tie inside the arm, so its flush.
Maybe I will incorporate that into the normal Arm ... What to Buy?
2x GBM2804 Hollow Shaft (http://www.banggood.com/RCTimer-BGM2804-100T-Brushless-Gimbal-Motor-Hollow-Shaft-p-951199.html)
4x Vibration Damper (http://www.banggood.com/Anti-vibration-Rubber-Shock-Absorber-Ball-AV-Ball-150g-p-917595.html)
1x Gimbal Controller (Alexmos(preferably Mini), Storm32, etc.)
1x Double Sided Velcro ca. 8mm wide and 1mm thick (buy something like this and cut down to 8mm : http://www.banggood.com/4_5m-10mm-Velcro-Sticky-Adhesive-Hook-and-Loop-Tape-Fasten-Stitch-Cable-Tie-Wrap-Cord-Straps-p-1031161.html)
4x M3x5 Socket Cap Hex(2x if you want to save some weight)
8x M3x6 Socket Cap Hex(4x if you want to save even more weight)
4x M3x8 or M3x10 Countersink Hex
4x M3 Hex Nut
some 2,5mm Zip Ties
Double sided Tape Optional:
1x FPV-Cable (http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__57996__Super_Slim_GoPro_3_A_V_Cable_And_Power_Lead_For_FPV_UK_Warehouse_.html?strSearch=slim%20fp) SimpleBGC Settings: (I've uploaded my profile file aswell, you can just flash that file via the GUI)
Roll P: 12 I: 0.45 D: 18
Pitch P: 10 I: 0.5 D: 12 Motor Config:
Roll Power: 100
Pitch Power 80 Sensor:
Axis TOP: -Z
Right: Y Things I want to change in the near future:
  • change to Alexmos Mini Board
  • enclosure/mount for Alexmos Mini on BaseFront
  • proper closed Board Camera mount/enclosure
  • maybe add support for other quads ? Let me know
  • Build Guide

Resolution:

0,1 or 0,2

Infill:

30% - 50%

Notes: Long Holes need support!

description.text: This is a redesigned prusa SAE x carriage, for the motor side. It was done in solidworks 2010, and is designed with printability as it's main goal. Prepare for your next Nerf insurgency with this Tactical Rail Reel! It is intended to be used with a grappling hook or other Dart that you wish to retrieve. Point, shoot, and wind in your prey. The print incorporates a few interesting features. There is a one-way ratcheting mechanism that keeps the Spindle from spinning freely (It can be released with a lever on the side.) The Mount has ridges on the underside so that it snaps in position on your Nerf gun’s tactical rail. The knob incorporates a planetary gear (uses Emmett’s Gear Bearing and Customizer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451) so that cable retrieval is 3x faster than turning the Spindle directly. And a cable guide that can be used when winding in your line. Sketchup files are included.
And I use Slic3R for GCode generation.

Putting the Parts Together Putting the parts of the linear slide together is pretty self-explanatory as it is pretty obvious where everything goes once all of the parts are printed. Drill them into the bottom of the cylinder wherever your motor's mounting holes will be located.

title: GV Tyre Truer MKII for slot cars 1:32 scale

description.text:
An improved version of my previous Tyre Truer.
The major revision is in the swing arm eliminating the cantilever tyre.
Beefed-up the pulleys wheels and designed in one piece construction for the base mainly to to avoid possible misalignments.

Printer:

K8400

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Constructional notes:
The tyre shaft is 80 mm long, OD 3/32" with 3 or 4 bronze bearings (one side flange only). The sanding wheel is a market component with shaft OD 6 mm and sanding wheel OD 25 mm. The register screw is a regular M3, 40 mm long with the head turned down to a hair less than 4 mm. The stop screw is a 25 mm long M3.
The motor has an OD of 28 mm from the scrap box. OD motor shaft 2 mm (here you might need to adapt to what you have at hand.
Motor pulley is pressed in the shaft (mine is from brass). It is recommended to have a set of reamers to ensure precise holes and a set of threading taps M3-M5. You need around 30 mm length of precise 5 mm rod for the pivoting of the swing arm.
For the pulleys use o-rings of suitable length.
Have fun and happy slot car races!

Here's something I don't actually expect anyone to print.  You'd have to have the exact same Mastech meter I have but I figure it's good for idea fodder.  The design holds two neodymium magnets (11.76 x 1.6 mm) keeping them .5mm from the surface (may want to thin that just a touch more).  The channel in the center is there to allow bending to get the curved posts into their respective cups and the meter hangs on any metal surface.  
NOTE:  if you DO want to print this for your meter, scale the width down just a touch (about 1.5 mm PLA, ABS will probably shrink more so maybe .5?).  I ended up sanding down the nubs slightly to get the flat surface to actually rest flat.

My towel was always in a semi-humid state hanging over the shower's glass pane.  I decided to make two 3D printed brackets to hold a rod and make it easier to access the towel while keeping it dry.  As it turns out, the height is ideal and the brackets fit really snug.  Great success!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

200

Measured all dimensions First, to make sure the fixture would fit snugly, I measured the glass pane thickness and made the slots exactly for that size. Because the tolerance is +/- 0.5mm this was a perfect interference fit. Second, I looked at an example of another towel holder and measured the distance from the center of that rod to the wall. Finally, I found a rod from Crate & Barrel's clearance section for $5. It was the perfect length for my glass shower pane.

This is a universal ball and socket system I designed to mount small speakers, but I imagine there could be lots of uses. The center link is a 1/4" X bolt, length to suit.
  • Update: Per Cyclone's suggestion below, I added a double socket piece to make an "elbow". I mocked up what could be a helping-hand device. Thanks Cyclone!
    • The cap and ball should be flipped over to print (threads up on the cap, hex up on the ball). I used 3 shells for strength. You need to work the threads on and off a few times to get them working freely. Be careful, as you can scrape your knuckles on the sharp edges turning the nut on and off!

description.text: Mounts for Y-min, X-min, and X-max endstop switches for the Mosaic printer. This is one of the printers we use at the ProtoParadigm workshop ( http://www.protoparadigm.com ) and found this to be an invaluable, but simple upgrade, especially since the switches and electronics for the min endstops were already included in the Mosaic kit.

Y endstop mounts on the rear of the carriage, replacing the nylon spacer at the end of the rail.
The X endstop can be used for min or max by rotating it.  It mounts over the edge of the frame on the top of the machine, and stays in place by friction.
The switch mounts to the y-min endstop using two 3m screws with nuts (washers might be a good idea too).  The x switches mount using 3m screws screwed directly into the part, no need for nuts or washers.

description.text:
An air scrubber i decided to design.  use aquarium activated charcoal to fill the body of the unit and a foam filter for the intake end.  It will fit any 120mm fan.  Depending on the accuracy of your printer, you may need to use heat for assembly.   it should only take 4 screws to build the unit, the rest will be friction fit.  i used magnets to attach the fan guard.  the screens were made by setting the top and bottom to 0 the perimeters to 4 and the infill to 25%.  you may need to experiment..  
the filter really works well... and if you completely fill it, it should continue to filter for over a year depending on what you are filtering.

The T4 is probably the best quad on Thingiverse right now. Just one problem, the full size version isn't printable on a basic 8" entry level printer. Well, it wasn't printable; because now it's been CUT! I just imported the STL to Sketchup and split the model to make it fit on a 8" print bed. The resulting two pieces must be welded back together. I didn't add any interlocking parts or pins because I just don't think it'll be strong enough to keep the quad together. If there is enough interest I could see about coming up with an interlocking design. 
The best way I've found to weld printed parts together is to take some filament, about an inch or so; clamp it down in a dremel and run it along the seam. You'll find the right speed when you get in the groove. You may need do an initial tack weld with super glue to get the alignment just right on a flat surface.
Pieces of test to verify that the printer has calibrated the two axes. I have created two different parts in which the hole is printed  horizontally and vertically.

This is a replacement corner for wire cube storage systems like this one:
http://www.amazon.com/Safco-Model-Wire-Cubes-Black/dp/B000789RSQ/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1319357764&sr=8-2 It is slightly different from the normal design because of the limitations of printing. It is slightly more difficult to put together than the ones that come with a kit, but it holds stronger too and seems more resistant to breaking than the brittle material the normal corners are made of. Sorry for the poor photo, it's late and I got lazy and used a phone camera. Update: Sorry, forgot to upload STL file. It's there now.
I was able to print this on a Mosaic with no additional support structures.  The model itself has some supports built-in that will need to be snapped out with some pliers, but this is fairly easy.

comments.text: My girlfriend has a two-story rabbit condo built out of storage cubes, but we can't have it as stable as we'd like because the corner pieces are only one-sided.  How possible would it be to crank out a double-sided one of these?

comments.text: The gap height variable refers to the width of the gap excluding the teeth.  It's just the space between the surfaces the teeth are a part of.  The gap is a bit wider than the wire corner, and the teeth form a gap just smaller, so that the part has to flex a bit as the wire is pushed into place, but is held firmly once it is situated between teeth.

comments.text: Ok, so the normal design, for the corners that ship with these, has teeth on both sides in those bottom channels.  Because of the impracticality of trying to print those teeth over the gap (over nothing), I decided to just print the other wall of that gap at the height the teeth would have extended to, hoping that wall would provide the pressure for the teeth only on the other side to hold it in place.  This is what I attribute to the hold being stronger, but the act of getting it in place more difficult.

description.text:
DIY Multi-purpose Light Build
Uses: Work light, aquarium light, plant grow light, UV light, Ect...
I've built several of these lights and I love them. They are very useful and easy to build out of old parts you probably have lying around. I've been using them as work lights, aquarium lights, plant grow lights, and for some UV light fun.
The hope is that this will be a very cheap and easy build. The housing is sized for a snug press fit of an 80mm x 80mm CPU fan. It accepts a range different sized heat sinks, or you can use small piece of metal sheeting to sink the LED's. I've had success using leftover 12V power supplies from old routers. The fan is wired directly to the power supply and the LED's are wired in series. I'd recommend using an LM317 to control current to the LED's. Check wikipedia for info. Since this setup is very well cooled my lights lave lasted thousands of hours so far without any failures. I'd recommend thermal adhesive to attach the LED's to the heat sink and caulk or epoxy to secure the heat sink to the light housing. GL building!

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20% honeycomb

Notes: A single shell is sufficient. Prints in just over 4 hours.
The plants in the pictures are roma tomatoes being hydroponically grown as an experiment.

title: Maze gyro generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is based on Maze circle generator. You may change the following parameters to generate a maze gyro, different every time:
  • radius
  • spacing
  • wall_height
  • wall_thickness
  • cblocks
  • rblocks
  • ring
    • You may roll it on 720 degrees. This may resemble new mazes on both sides. It always makes me think of a movie "Maze Runner". To avoid overlapping between rings, you may try different values of the spacing parameter. The 0.6 mm spacing is suitable for my printer with 0.2 mm layer height and 0.6 mm Bottom/Top thickness. Although 0.6 mm spacing seems suitable for most situations, I think it's different for different 3DP, filaments and settings. That's why I makes the spacing parameter changeable.
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English
    • Find all my mazes in the collection "maze generators".

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Do you want to know how to create mazes with OpenSCAD? The following documents may help.
  • Manual maze
  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze
